description:
On 19 May, the Finnish government decides to lay down provisions on restrictions for restaurants:
- the number of seats in restaurants, cafes, and bars would be reduced in order for customers to maintain a sufficient distance between one another
- customers must be provided with instructions on how to avoid contracting the virus
-  food and beverage service providers must make sure to adequately clean all surfaces and objects that customers touch
- customers are not allowed to serve or dish out their own food or drinks, for example, at a buffet table
- food and beverage service businesses are allowed to be open to customers between 06:00-23:00
- alcohol may served only between 09:00 - 22:00; if a customer buys an alcoholic beverage before 22:00, then it must be consumed by 23:00
- food and beverage services must draw up a plan on how to implement these regulations

description:
The Finnish government announces on 17 June that it will ease restrictions on food and beverage services, beginning on 22 June. The following restrictions have been changed:
- businesses may open at 04:00 and must close by 02:00
- buffets are once again permitted
- three-quarters of the number of persons permitted in the serving license or building plan may be present in the indoor premises at one time

All customers are still required to have their own seat and businesses must arrange their indoor and outdoor furniture to maintain a safe distance between one another. These businesses must also ensure that customers can wash or sanitise their hands upon arrival and have visible instructions on handwashing, maintaining safe distances, and other measures to prevent the spread of COVID19. On 29 September, the Finnish government decides to extend restrictions, ending the previous policy.
 UPDATE: On 29 September, the Finnish government decides to extend restrictions, ending the previous policy.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Restaurants

description:
The Region of Kymenlaakso, Finland, bans all visits in many of its health care providers including hospitals of Pohjois-Kyme, Karhula, and Hamina as well as in the rehabilitation center Hoikku from 30 November 2020 until 31 December 2020. 

This decision does not apply to the psychiatric hospital of Kymenlaakso, palliative care units of Villa Apila and Villa Meri, child ward, or the support persons for mothers in labor. Exceptions are also made for individuals that are in a critical state or near-death.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On 13 May, Finland's Ministry of Social Affairs and Health issues new guidelines for facilities providing 24-hour care and treatment. These guidelines include that staff who come into close contact with patients must wear disposable surgical nose-masks or washable or disposable fabric masks that cover their nose and mouth in order to protect against any disease.
